title: Isaiah Chapter 64 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 64 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 64 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 64.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 64:1 express a desire for God to do?
options: Rend the heavens and come down
Write His laws on the stone tablets
questions.correctAnswer: Rend the heavens and come down
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:1 expresses a wish for God to rend the heavens and come down, demonstrating His power.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 64:2, what causes the waters to boil?
questions.correctAnswer: Melting fire
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:2 says that melting fire burneth and causes the waters to boil.

questions.question: In Isaiah 64:3, what flowed down at God's presence?
questions.correctAnswer: Mountains
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:3 states that the mountains flowed down at God's presence.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 64:4, what has no one seen or heard besides God?
options: What He has prepared for those who wait for Him
questions.correctAnswer: What He has prepared for those who wait for Him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:4 says that no one has seen or heard what God has prepared for those who wait for Him.

questions.question: Who does Isaiah 64:5 say God meets?
options: Those who rejoice and work righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: Those who rejoice and work righteousness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:5 states that God meets those who rejoice and work righteousness and remember His ways.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 64:6 describe our righteousnesses?
questions.correctAnswer: As filthy rags
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:6 says all our righteousnesses are as filthy rags.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 64:7 says there is no one who calls upon God's name.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:7 states that there is none that calleth upon God's name.

questions.question: In Isaiah 64:8, what metaphor is used to describe God's relationship with His people?
questions.correctAnswer: Potter and clay
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:8 compares God to a potter and His people to clay, indicating His shaping power.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 64:9 ask God not to do?
questions.correctAnswer: Be wroth very sore
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:9 pleads with God not to be very angry or remember iniquity forever.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 64:10, what has become a wilderness?
options: Thy holy cities, Zion, and Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Thy holy cities, Zion, and Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:10 describes the holy cities, Zion, and Jerusalem as a wilderness and desolation.

questions.question: What happened to the house where the fathers praised God, according to Isaiah 64:11?
options: It was burned up with fire
questions.correctAnswer: It was burned up with fire
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:11 states that the beautiful house was burned up with fire.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 64:12 asks if God will hold His peace and afflict the people very sore.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:12 questions whether God will hold His peace and afflict the people sorely.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Isaiah 64:8: 'But now, O LORD, thou art our ______; we are the clay, and thou our potter.'
questions.correctAnswer: Father
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:8 says, 'But now, O LORD, thou art our father; we are the clay, and thou our potter.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 64:6, what happens to us like a leaf?
questions.correctAnswer: We all do fade
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:6 says, 'we all do fade as a leaf.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 64:2 says that God's name is made known to His friends.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:2 says God's name is made known to His adversaries, not friends.

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 64 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 64 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with feelings of unworthiness before God due to past mistakes. Based on Isaiah 64, what biblical truth would you share about how God views our righteousness?
options: Our righteousness is as filthy rags before God
Our righteousness is perfect and acceptable to God
God does not consider righteousness important
Righteousness alone can save us without God's mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Our righteousness is as filthy rags before God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:6 states that all our righteousnesses are as filthy rags, reminding us that human efforts are insufficient and we must rely on God's grace. This teaches humility and dependence on God (Isaiah 64:5, 64:7, 64:9).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 64 teach us about perseverance through trials and waiting on God?
options: God has prepared wonderful things for those who wait for Him
Waiting on God leads to disappointment
God does not reward those who wait
Patience is not necessary in the Christian life
questions.correctAnswer: God has prepared wonderful things for those who wait for Him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:4 highlights that God has prepared things beyond human understanding for those who wait for Him, encouraging believers to trust and persevere during difficult times (Isaiah 64:1, 64:5, 64:9).

questions.question: A believer wants to grow in humility and recognizes they are clay in God's hands. What biblical truth from Isaiah 64 supports this understanding?
options: We are the clay and God is the potter
We are masters of our own destiny
God does not shape our lives
We create ourselves without God's help
questions.correctAnswer: We are the clay and God is the potter
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:8 describes God as the potter and us as the clay, teaching humility and trust in God's sovereign shaping of our lives, which is essential for contentment and spiritual growth (Isaiah 64:6, 64:9, 64:12).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 64 instruct believers about confessing sin and seeking God's mercy?
options: We should acknowledge our sins and ask God not to remember iniquity forever
We should hide our sins and rely on self-justification
Confession is unnecessary if we feel sorry
God will remember our sins no matter what
questions.correctAnswer: We should acknowledge our sins and ask God not to remember iniquity forever
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:9 teaches believers to beseech God not to remember iniquity forever, emphasizing confession and seeking mercy as part of a humble and faithful relationship with God (Isaiah 64:5, 64:6, 64:7).

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because their place of worship is in ruin. What hope or perspective does Isaiah 64 offer about God's relationship with His people despite such circumstances?
options: God is still our Father and we are His people
The condition of the building reflects God's rejection
Worship is impossible without a perfect temple
questions.correctAnswer: God is still our Father and we are His people
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:8-9 reassures that despite desolation (64:10-11), God remains our Father and we remain His people, encouraging faith and perseverance through trials (Isaiah 64:5, 64:12).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 64 encourage believers to respond to God's hiddenness or seeming silence during difficult times?
options: Continue to call upon God's name and trust Him despite feeling hidden
Stop praying because God has hidden His face
Assume God has rejected them permanently
Ignore God and focus only on self
questions.correctAnswer: Continue to call upon God's name and trust Him despite feeling hidden
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:7 acknowledges God's face being hidden but emphasizes the need to call upon His name and seek Him, teaching perseverance in prayer and faith in trials (Isaiah 64:9, 64:12).

questions.question: How does the imagery of mountains flowing down in Isaiah 64 relate to God's power and presence in our lives?
options: It shows God's overwhelming power to change circumstances
It suggests mountains are unmovable and permanent
It means God is distant and uninvolved
It teaches that only natural disasters matter
questions.correctAnswer: It shows God's overwhelming power to change circumstances
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:1-3 describes mighty mountains flowing down at God's presence, symbolizing His power to intervene mightily in situations, encouraging trust in His sovereignty (Isaiah 64:2, 64:3, 64:12).

questions.question: A believer is wondering how obedience relates to joy in their relationship with God. What lesson does Isaiah 64 provide?
options: God meets those who rejoice and work righteousness
Obedience is only about rules, not joy
God does not notice those who obey
questions.correctAnswer: God meets those who rejoice and work righteousness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:5 explains that God meets those who rejoice and work righteousness, linking obedience with joy and God's presence, encouraging active faith and righteous living (Isaiah 64:4, 64:6).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 64 teach about the consequence of sin and the need for repentance?
options: Our iniquities have taken us away like the wind
questions.correctAnswer: Our iniquities have taken us away like the wind
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:6 describes how iniquities have taken us away like the wind, illustrating the destructive power of sin and the urgent need for repentance and seeking God's mercy (Isaiah 64:7, 64:9, 64:12).

questions.question: A fellow believer asks how they should view their work and righteousness in light of God's holiness. What does Isaiah 64 teach about that?
options: Our works are like filthy rags apart from God's grace
Our works earn God's favor fully
questions.correctAnswer: Our works are like filthy rags apart from God's grace
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:6 compares our righteousness to filthy rags, teaching that human efforts alone cannot justify us and we must rely on God's grace and mercy (Isaiah 64:5, 64:7, 64:9).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 64 teach about God's readiness to save despite our sinfulness?
options: Though we have sinned, we shall be saved
questions.correctAnswer: Though we have sinned, we shall be saved
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:5 acknowledges sin but affirms salvation for those who continue in righteousness and remember God, emphasizing hope and God's mercy (Isaiah 64:7, 64:9, 64:12).

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 64, God has never done anything terrible or unexpected that causes nations to tremble.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:3 states that God did terrible things which were unexpected, causing mountains to flow down and nations to tremble, affirming His mighty power.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 64 teaches that God's holy cities like Zion and Jerusalem are flourishing without any desolation.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:10-11 describes Zion and Jerusalem as wilderness and desolation, showing the consequences of sin and the need for God's restoration.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "But now, O LORD, thou art our _____; we are the clay, and thou our potter; and we all are the work of thy hand."
questions.correctAnswer: Father
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:8 calls God our Father, emphasizing a personal and caring relationship where He shapes and sustains us like a potter with clay.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 64 teach about the appropriate response when God afflicts His people due to their sins?
options: We should humbly seek God's mercy and repent
questions.correctAnswer: We should humbly seek God's mercy and repent
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:9-12 shows the people pleading for God's mercy and acknowledging their sins, a model for humble repentance and trust in God's restoration.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 64 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 64.

questions.question: In Isaiah 64:1, the imagery of 'rend the heavens' and 'mountains might flow down' primarily symbolizes what?
questions.correctAnswer: God's powerful intervention in history
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:1 uses vivid natural imagery to depict God's mighty presence and intervention, symbolizing divine power shaking the cosmos to demonstrate His authority.

questions.question: The phrase 'thy name known to thine adversaries' in Isaiah 64:2 implies what theological concept?
options: The manifestation of God’s holiness before enemies
The defeat of Israel’s enemies through human strength
questions.correctAnswer: The manifestation of God’s holiness before enemies
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:2 highlights God making His name known to adversaries, emphasizing that God's holiness and power cause nations to tremble before Him.

questions.question: Isaiah 64:4 says, 'neither hath the eye seen, nor ear heard'—which New Testament passage echoes this phrase to describe God’s blessings?
questions.correctAnswer: 1 Corinthians 2:9
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 2:9 directly quotes this phrase from Isaiah 64:4 to express the incomprehensible blessings God has prepared for those who love Him.

questions.question: What literary device is predominant in Isaiah 64:6 with the comparison 'our righteousnesses are as filthy rags'?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:6 uses a simile comparing human righteousness to 'filthy rags,' emphasizing its impurity relative to God's holiness.

questions.question: The term 'potter' in Isaiah 64:8 reflects what Old Testament theme?
options: God as the Creator shaping His people
The temple as a house of clay
questions.correctAnswer: God as the Creator shaping His people
questions.explanation: The potter metaphor in Isaiah 64:8 illustrates God’s sovereign authority over His people, shaping and molding them according to His will, a theme also found in Jeremiah 18.

questions.question: In the historical context of Isaiah 64, what does the desolation of Jerusalem and Zion (Isaiah 64:10) represent?
options: The aftermath of exile and divine judgment
A literal desertification due to drought
Conquest by foreign armies unrelated to sin
A prophetic vision of future prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: The aftermath of exile and divine judgment
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:10 reflects the historical reality of Jerusalem’s destruction as a consequence of Israel’s sin and God’s judgment, a common theme in prophetic literature.

questions.question: Which form of parallelism is evident in Isaiah 64:5 when contrasting 'he that rejoiceth and worketh righteousness' with God's wrath?
questions.correctAnswer: Antithetic parallelism
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:5 contrasts righteous rejoicing with God's wrath over sin, exemplifying antithetic parallelism by juxtaposing opposing ideas.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 64:7 suggests that no one calls upon God's name or seeks Him because God has hidden His face due to Israel’s iniquities.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:7 clearly states that no one calls on God because He has hidden His face as a consequence of their sins.

questions.question: The phrase 'we all do fade as a leaf' in Isaiah 64:6 can be interpreted as which of the following?
options: The transient nature of human life
questions.correctAnswer: The transient nature of human life
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:6 uses the fading leaf as a metaphor for human frailty and mortality, underscoring the fleetingness of life.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 64 portray the relationship between sin and divine judgment?
options: Sin causes God to hide His face and bring affliction
Sin has no effect on God’s disposition
questions.correctAnswer: Sin causes God to hide His face and bring affliction
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:7 and 64:12 emphasize that Israel’s sin leads God to hide His face and afflict His people, illustrating the connection between sin and judgment.

questions.question: In Isaiah 64:9, the plea 'neither remember iniquity forever' suggests what aspect of God's nature?
options: God’s mercy and willingness to forgive
questions.correctAnswer: God’s mercy and willingness to forgive
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:9 reflects a heartfelt plea for God’s mercy, highlighting His willingness to forgive and not remember sin eternally.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'holy and beautiful house' in Isaiah 64:11 being burned with fire?
options: Symbolizes the destruction of the temple and loss of worship center
Represents a natural wildfire unrelated to sin
Indicates a future temple to be built
Describes a metaphor for personal repentance
questions.correctAnswer: Symbolizes the destruction of the temple and loss of worship center
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:11 mourns the temple’s destruction by fire, symbolizing the loss of the sacred place where ancestors praised God, reflecting national calamity.

questions.question: Which ancient Near Eastern cultural concept is echoed in Isaiah 64:8’s metaphor of God as potter and Israel as clay?
options: Divine sovereignty over creation and human fate
questions.correctAnswer: Divine sovereignty over creation and human fate
questions.explanation: The potter/clay metaphor in Isaiah 64:8 reflects a widespread ancient Near Eastern motif of gods shaping humans, here emphasizing Yahweh’s sovereign control.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 64:3’s description of God coming down and mountains flowing down serve as a foreshadowing in biblical typology?
options: Anticipation of theophanies and later divine interventions
questions.correctAnswer: Anticipation of theophanies and later divine interventions
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:3 uses theophanic imagery that foreshadows God’s dramatic appearances in Scripture, such as Sinai and later New Testament manifestations.

questions.question: Isaiah 64:12’s question 'Wilt thou hold thy peace, and afflict us very sore?' reflects what element of prophetic prayer?
options: A lament and urgent plea for God’s intervention
questions.correctAnswer: A lament and urgent plea for God’s intervention
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:12 expresses the prophet’s lament and desperate appeal for God not to remain silent but to act and relieve suffering.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 64 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 64 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What imagery does Isaiah 64:1 use to describe God's powerful intervention?
options: God rending the heavens and mountains flowing down
God calming the seas and stilling the winds
God creating the stars and setting their courses
God sending angels to fight for His people
questions.correctAnswer: God rending the heavens and mountains flowing down
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:1 portrays God as powerful and majestic, capable of 'rending the heavens' and causing mountains to flow down, emphasizing His sovereign power over creation. Similar images appear in Exodus 19:18, Psalm 97:5, Nahum 1:5, and Hebrews 12:26 as demonstrations of God's mighty presence.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 64:4, what has not been heard or seen besides what God has prepared for those who wait for Him?
questions.correctAnswer: The things God has prepared
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:4 emphasizes God's unique and extraordinary plans for those who wait on Him, plans beyond human perception or experience. This theme is consistent with 1 Corinthians 2:9, Ephesians 3:20, Romans 11:33, and Psalm 31:19 concerning God's marvelous works for His people.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 64:6 describe human righteousness in contrast to God's holiness?
questions.correctAnswer: As filthy rags
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:6 starkly contrasts human righteousness to God's holiness, calling them 'filthy rags,' underscoring humanity's sinfulness and need for divine grace. This metaphor is echoed in Job 13:26, Romans 3:10-12, Isaiah 6:5, and Revelation 3:17, highlighting human moral insufficiency apart from God.

questions.question: What metaphor does Isaiah 64:8 use to describe God's relationship to humanity?
options: God as the potter, and we are the clay
God as the shepherd, and we are the sheep
God as the king, and we are the subjects
God as the light, and we are the darkness
questions.correctAnswer: God as the potter, and we are the clay
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:8 uses the potter and clay metaphor to illustrate God's sovereignty and creative authority over humanity, who are formed and shaped by Him. This imagery aligns with Jeremiah 18:6, Romans 9:21, Psalm 95:6, and 2 Timothy 2:20-21, emphasizing God's molding of His people.

questions.question: What is the lament expressed in Isaiah 64:10 regarding Jerusalem and Zion?
options: They are described as wilderness and desolation
They are praised as holy and restored
They are said to be flourishing and full of joy
They are declared to be invincible and victorious
questions.correctAnswer: They are described as wilderness and desolation
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:10 laments the devastation of Jerusalem and Zion, portraying them as wilderness and desolation, reflecting the consequences of sin and judgment. Similar lamentations occur in Lamentations 1:1-4, Jeremiah 4:23-26, Ezekiel 22:4, and Psalm 79:1-5, expressing sorrow over the ruin of God's people and city.

questions.question: In Isaiah 64:5, which two characteristics define those whom God meets?
options: Those who rejoice and work righteousness
Those who are wealthy and powerful
Those who are silent and humble
questions.correctAnswer: Those who rejoice and work righteousness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:5 highlights that God meets those who rejoice and practice righteousness, indicating His favor on those living in obedience and joy. This is consistent with Psalm 1:1-3, Matthew 5:6, Romans 14:17, and Hebrews 11:6, emphasizing the blessedness of righteous living.

questions.question: Which phrase in Isaiah 64:7 explains why no one calls upon God's name or seeks Him?
options: Because God has hidden His face due to their iniquities
Because God is too distant and unapproachable
Because God has condemned all people to death
Because God has forgotten His covenant
questions.correctAnswer: Because God has hidden His face due to their iniquities
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:7 reveals that God's hidden face, caused by human sin, results in a lack of seeking Him, demonstrating the relational barrier sin creates. This theme is echoed in Psalm 44:24, Isaiah 59:2, Exodus 33:3, and Lamentations 3:44, showing how sin disrupts fellowship with God.

questions.question: What plea does the people make to God in Isaiah 64:9?
options: Do not be angry forever and remember iniquity no more
Send judgment swiftly upon the wicked
Bring fire from heaven to consume enemies
Restore the temple to its former glory
questions.correctAnswer: Do not be angry forever and remember iniquity no more
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:9 petitions God to relent in His anger and not remember sins forever, pleading for mercy and restoration. This plea corresponds with Psalm 103:8-12, Micah 7:18-19, Nehemiah 9:31, and Joel 2:13, emphasizing God's readiness to forgive upon genuine repentance.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 64:2, why does God cause the waters to boil with fiery heat?
options: To make His name known to His adversaries
To bring rain and fertility to the land
questions.correctAnswer: To make His name known to His adversaries
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:2 explains that the fiery boiling is a manifestation of God's power intended to reveal His name to adversaries so that nations would tremble. This divine revelation of power is also seen in Exodus 9:23-24, Psalm 97:3-6, Nahum 1:5-6, and Romans 9:17.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 64:3 say about the nature of God's interventions?
options: God does terrible and unexpected things
God acts only through gradual changes
God remains silent and does not intervene
God works only through human leaders
questions.correctAnswer: God does terrible and unexpected things
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:3 describes God's interventions as 'terrible things which we looked not for,' emphasizing His sovereign and awe-inspiring acts beyond human expectation. This is paralleled in Exodus 14:21-22, Psalm 77:14, Isaiah 40:26, and Hebrews 10:31, showing God's transcendent power.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 64:11 describe the state of the house where the fathers praised God?
options: Burned up with fire and laid waste
Guarded by angels day and night
questions.correctAnswer: Burned up with fire and laid waste
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:11 laments the destruction of the sacred temple, describing it as burned and desolate, reflecting the consequences of judgment. This is echoed in 2 Kings 25:9, Lamentations 2:7, Ezekiel 10:18-19, and Jeremiah 52:12, showing the devastating effects of divine judgment on the sanctuary.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 64:12 ask God regarding His response to the people's suffering?
options: Will God hold His peace and afflict them very sore?
Will God send His angels to deliver them?
Will God restore the land and prosper them?
Will God exalt the humble and humble the proud?
questions.correctAnswer: Will God hold His peace and afflict them very sore?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:12 questions whether God will remain silent while afflicting His people severely, expressing a plea for divine intervention. This echoes themes in Psalm 13:1, Habakkuk 1:2, Jeremiah 14:10, and Lamentations 3:26, concerning God's silence amid suffering.

questions.question: In Isaiah 64:5, what is the outcome promised to those who remember God in His ways despite His wrath?
options: They shall be exalted above others
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be saved
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:5 assures that those who rejoice, work righteousness, and remember God will ultimately be saved despite God's anger. This assurance aligns with Isaiah 43:2, Psalm 34:17, Romans 10:9, and 1 Peter 1:5 highlighting salvation through faith and obedience.

questions.question: Which natural elements are used in Isaiah 64:6 to symbolize human frailty and sin?
options: A fading leaf and the wind
A flowing river and the sun
questions.correctAnswer: A fading leaf and the wind
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:6 uses the imagery of a fading leaf and wind to depict human weakness and the transient nature of sin's consequences. Similar metaphors are found in Psalm 102:3, James 1:10, Ecclesiastes 1:14, and Matthew 6:19-20, emphasizing human mortality and frailty.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 64:7 say about people’s responsiveness to God’s name in their current state?
options: None calls upon His name or stirs up himself to take hold of Him
Many call upon His name with joy and confidence
Only the priests call upon His name daily
The people call upon His name but are ignored
questions.correctAnswer: None calls upon His name or stirs up himself to take hold of Him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 64:7 reveals a spiritual deadness where no one calls upon God's name or eagerly seeks Him, due to divine hiddenness caused by sin. This reflects themes in Psalm 22:1, Isaiah 59:1-2, Romans 3:11, and Hosea 5:15 about alienation from God through sin.
